title: Why I Chose the Name 'lost'
description: A short reflection on getting distracted, getting absorbed, and finding an identity in the word 'lost'.
fullContent:
I Get Lost. A Lot.

I get distracted really easily.

Sometimes I'm lost in the real world — zoning out, missing what's happening around me. Other times, I'm lost in my own work, deep into something that may or may not even be useful in the end.

But I've realized something over time.

Being lost isn't always a bad thing.

Lost in Thought, Lost in Work

When I'm working on something I enjoy, I disappear into it. Time passes without me noticing. I jump between ideas, experiments, and random rabbit holes.

Not all of it leads somewhere meaningful.

But some of my best learning moments came from being lost — not following a plan, just curiosity pulling me forward.

LostLuinor Energy

One of my favorite Beyblades growing up was LostLuinor.

It wasn't just about power. It had attitude. Chaos. Spin-steal. It survived by adapting.

That name stuck with me.

There was something cool about embracing the word “lost” instead of running from it.

A Hacker Name, A Gaming Alias

“lost” also just works.

It sounds clean. Minimal. A little mysterious.

As a hacker-style name, it fits — someone who doesn't follow straight paths, who explores systems, breaks things, figures stuff out the long way.

As a gaming alias, it feels right too. Simple, memorable, and not trying too hard.

Not Lost — Just Exploring

I don't think being lost means being clueless.

Sometimes it just means you're exploring without a map.

That's how I learn. That's how I build. That's how I end up discovering things I wouldn't have found otherwise.

So yeah — I chose the name “lost”.

Not because I don't know where I'm going.

But because I'm okay taking the long way there.
